Subject: Screen men age 65-80 with ultrasound once
General Patient Text: n/a

Topic heading: Aorta: The body's main blood vessel
Subject: Talk to your provider to see if you need a test
General Patient Text:
Your provider may ask for an ultrasound of your belly
to detect a bulge in the main blood vessel 
(the bulge is nicknamed AAA 
for short or
Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm)
If the bulge grows it can burst and cause death.

Subject: Benefits of physical activity
General Patient Text:
Physical activity
prevents heart disease, cancer, depression and [[more; https://www.reframehealthlab.com/23-and-12-hours/]]

Subject: Recommended physical activity
General Patient Text:
The recommended minimum amount of physical activity
is 150 minutes a week of moderate intensity exercise. 
Definition of moderate intensity:
while you are active you have enough breath to say a short sentence but not enough to sing
•[[Guideline for age 18-64; https://csepguidelines.ca/guidelines/adults-18-64/]]
•[[Guildeline for age 65+; https://csepguidelines.ca/guidelines/adults-65/]]

Subject: Information
General Patient Text:
•Physical exercise and a healthy diet keep your bones strong and prevent Osteoporosis.
•Some providers (Rainbow Health Ontario) recommend that all patients on hormone therapy ensure a daily intake of 1200 mg of calcium (diet
+ supplementation) and 1000 IU of vitamin D. 
More information on [[calcium and vitamin D; https://osteoporosis.ca/nutrition/]]

•Bone density testing is generally recommended for everyone at age 65 in Canada.

•You may need bone density testing earlier if: you had an orchiectomy (removal of the testes) or you are/were on a testosterone or puberty blocker (such as spironolactone, cyproterone or Lupron), and you were taking no/low doses of hormone therapy.

•You may also need testing earlier if you have other [[risk factors; https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/chronic-diseases/osteoporosis.html]].These are the same risk factors as for cisgender patients. Discuss any concerns you may have with your primary care provider.

•Here is a risk calculator used to determine your 10-year fracture risk: click [[here; https://www.sheffield.ac.uk/FRAX/]].
 If you have been medically transitioning, consider using an average of both the female and male calculators to calculate your own fracture risk.
Health Provider Text:
•All trans women and people on the transfeminine spectrum should undergo bone density screening as per the current guidelines for the general population.

•For a low risk patient without additional risk factors in Canada, screening usually begins at age 65.

•As per the current guidelines for the general population, screening with BMD should be considered for younger patients who have [[risk factors for osteoporosis; https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/chronic-diseases/osteoporosis.html]]

•For trans women and people on the transfeminine spectrum, this also includes anyone who, regardless of age:
1)Has a history of hypogonadism/gonadectomy, and a history of insufficient (no/low-dose/intermittent) hormone replacement (UCSF recommends > 5 years without hormones to qualify; RHO recommends > 2 years; Endrocine Society, ISCD and TransCare BC do not specify a minimum amount of time).
2)A history of taking an anti-androgen/GnRH analogue without exogenous hormones (RHO, ISCD).
3)Is not adherent to hormone therapy or has taken it intermittently (Endocrine Society, TransCare BC).
•On the other hand, the Endocrine Society suggests considering BMD testing at baseline in all trans feminine patients.
•The RHO recommends that all patients on hormone therapy ensure a daily intake of 1200 mg of calcium and 1000 IU of vitamin D.

Subject: Tips and Resources
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text:
•When assessing for osteoporosis, consider assessing risk using an average of the results obtained using both a female and male calculator [[risk calculator; https://www.sheffield.ac.uk/FRAX/]] (UCSF).
•The ISCD suggests that the Z-score should generally be derived from comparison to the reference data of the patient’s affirmed gender for binary transgender patients (i.e. who identify as solely male or female), and to the gender assigned at birth in non-binary patients (ISCD).

Subject: Prevent Breast Cancer
General Patient Text:
•Limit alcohol (see our substance use info)
•Don't smoke
•Control your weight
•Be physically active (see our physical activity info for this)
•Breastfeed if you are able
•Limit time on hormone therapy
[[more; https://www.mycanceriq.ca/Cancers/Risk]]

Click on this [[link to know if you are at high risk of breast cancer; https://www.cancer.ca/en/prevention-and-screening/reduce-cancer-risk/find-cancer-early/get-screened-for-breast-cancer/at-high-risk-for-breast-cancer/?region=on]]

Mammograms for healthy women below age 50 
with no symptoms, no breast problems
and no additional risks 
is not recommended.
[[risks; http://www.cancer.ca/en/cancer-information/cancer-type/breast/risks/?region=on]]
[[harms of mammograms; https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UZlY6Q4m-MM]]
DISCUSS WITH YOUR HEALTH CARE PROVIDER.

Subject:
Get tested for Breast Cancer 
at age 50-74
General Patient Text:
Get a mammogram every 2-3 years:
You may need one earlier or more often
if you have risks or symptoms.
[[more; http://www.cancer.ca/en/cancer-information/cancer-type/breast/risks/?region=on]]

Subject: Age 75 and over
General Patient Text:
Research does not recommend mammograms age 75 and over, 
but if you are healthy you may discuss further testing with your health care provider.

Subject: Prevent and screen for Breast Cancer
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text:
Counsel patients to:
•Limit alcohol (see our substance use info)
•Not smoke
•Control their weight
•Be physically active (see our app info for this)
•Breastfeed if able
•Limit time on hormone therapy
[[a risk calculator for patients; https://www.mycanceriq.ca/Cancers/Risk]]

Screening Mammogram:
•Below age 50: Not recommended
[[canadiantaskforce recomendation; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/guidelines/published-guidelines/breast-cancer-update/]]
[[tool to explain harms to patient; https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UZlY6Q4m-MM]]
[[tool to explain harms to patient; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/tools-resources/breast-cancer-2/breast-cancer-risks-benefits-age-40-49/]]
•50-74:  Every 2-3 years
[[weak recommendation; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/guidelines/published-guidelines/breast-cancer-update/]]
•75+: Not recommended by canadiantaskforce.ca,but:
[[CFP  article 2019 on when to stop screening; https://www.cfp.ca/content/cfp/65/8/543.full.pdf]]

High risk patients:
•Known to have a gene mutation that increases their risk for breast cancer (e.g., BRCA1, BRCA2, TP53, PTEN, CDH1)
•First-degree relatives of someone who has a gene mutation that increases their risk for breast cancer (e.g., BRCA1, BRCA2, TP53, PTEN, CDH1), have already had genetic counselling and have chosen not to have genetic testing
•Have been assessed by a genetics clinic (using the IBIS or BOADICEA tools) as having a 25% or greater lifetime risk of breast cancer based on personal and family history
•Have had radiation therapy to the chest to treat another cancer or condition (e.g., Hodgkin lymphoma) before age 30 and at least 8 years ago
•First-degree relative (parent, brother, sister or child) of a carrier of a gene mutation (e.g. BRCA1, BRCA2, TP53, PTEN, CDH1) and has not had genetic counselling or genetic testing
•Personal or family history of breast or ovarian cancer suggestive of a hereditary breast cancer syndrome

Subject: Information
General Patient Text:
•        If you are taking estrogen and have breasts, you need regular screening mammograms depending on your age.
•        The recommendation is for you to have a mammogram every 2 years from age 50 to 74.
•        Some primary care providers may recommend that you only start undergoing mammograms at age 50 if you have been on estrogen for at least 5 years.
Health Provider Text:
•	Trans women and people on the transfeminine spectrum who are on feminizing hormone therapy should undergo breast cancer screening as per current guidelines for cis women.
•	The current recommendation is a mammogram every 2 years from age 50-74.
•	Some guidelines (such as those by RHO and UCSF) specify to only start once the patient has been on feminizing hormone therapy for > 5 years total (up to 10 years according to UCSF), whereas others do not specify a minimum hormone duration use.
• Note that the presence of breast implants generally necessitates diagnostic mammography rather than routine screening mammography (RHO)

Subject: Information
General Patient Text:
•	If you have not had top surgery to remove breast tissue in its entirety (also known as a mastectomy), you need a mammogram every 2 years from age 50 to 74.
•	You still need mammograms even if you have had a breast reduction (and not a mastectomy).
•	If you have had a mastectomy, discuss whether you need regular chest exams with your primary care provider; it is generally not the case.
Health Provider Text:
•	Trans men and people on the transmasculine spectrum who have not had a bilateral mastectomy should undergo breast cancer screening, as per the current guidelines for cis women.
•	The current recommendation for cis women is a mammogram every 2 years from age 50-74.
•	There is currently no reliable evidence on screening for trans men and people on the transmasculine spectrum patients who have had a mastectomy; consider discussing the unknown risks associated with residual breast tissue, as well as the possible technical limitations of mammography (UCSF).
•	Consider continuing regular monitoring for breast cancer even after mastectomy, as mastectomies usually do not remove breast tissue in its entirety; the Endocrine Society suggests conducting sub- and periareolar annual breast examinations if the patient has undergone a mastectomy, whereas UCSF cautions against it (not evidence-based).

Subject: Tips and Resources
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text:
•	Be mindful of the language you use when referring to traditionally gendered body parts, as certain words may make patients feel uncomfortable — consider following the patients lead with regards to terminology (e.g. some trans men may prefer to refer to their breasts as their “chest”).
•	Note that mastectomy typically does not involve the removal of all breast tissue, and that some may still remain in place, meaning that patients could still be at risk of breast cancer (TransCare BC).
•	If an abnormality is noted on the exam of a trans man who had a mastectomy, ultrasound +/- MRI is indicated as mammography is technically difficult or may be impossible (RHO).
•	[[Overview of breast cancer screening for trans men in Canada; https://www.cancer.ca/en/prevention-and-screening/reduce-cancer-risk/find-cancer-early/screening-in-lgbtq-communities/trans-men-and-chest-cancer-screening/?region=on]]
•	[[RHO guidelines; https://www.rainbowhealthontario.ca/wp-content/uploads/woocommerce_uploads/2019/12/Guidelines-FINAL-Dec-2019-iw2oti.pdf]]
•	[[UCSF Transcare guidelines; https://transcare.ucsf.edu/sites/transcare.ucsf.edu/files/Transgender-PGACG-6-17-16.pdf]]
•	[[Endocrine Society guidelines; https://academic.oup.com/jcem/article/102/11/3869/4157558]]

Subject: Screen
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text:
Age 50-74:
•FOBT or FIT (depending on province) every 2y or
•Flexible sigmoidoscopy every 10 years
•Colonoscopy not recommended in Canada for low risk: 1/2000 risk of perforation, no evidence yet,ongoing RCTs
[[canadian task force; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/guidelines/published-guidelines/colorectal-cancer/]]
[[CFP article on when to stop screening; https://www.cfp.ca/content/cfp/65/8/543.full.pdf]]
FOBT=Fecal occult blood test
FIT= Fecal immunochemical test
•Colonoscopy recommended for high risk patients
Click to see [[Canadian association of gastroenterology guideline 2018; https://www.cag-acg.org/images/publications/CAG_CPG_CRC_Screening_Aug2018.pdf]]

Subject: Get tested for Bowel Cancer
General Patient Text:
Age 50 to 74:
•Do a stool test ("poop test") every 2 years
(see your health care provider for a kit)
•Or do another test called
Flexible Sigmoidoscopy every 10 years 
(not common, discuss with your provider if available)
•Colonoscopy is not recommended if you have no symptoms or family history
of colon cancer.
It has a risk of perforation of the bowel of 1/2000

[[more; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/tools-resources/colorectal-cancer-for-patients-2/]]

Subject: Testing to detect early cancer may not be useful at age 75 and over
General Patient Text:
Most people do not need to be screened at this time, 
discuss with your provider if you prefer to be screened.
[[more; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/tools-resources/colorectal-cancer-for-patients-2/]]

Subject: Prevent Colon Cancer
General Patient Text:
•Be physically active
•Maintain a healthy body weight, [[bmi; https://cancer.ca/en/cancer-information/reduce-your-risk/have-a-healthy-body-weight/reduce-your-risk-of-cancer-with-a-healthy-body-weight]]
•Be a non-smoker and avoid second hand smoke
•[[more; http://www.cancer.ca/en/cancer-information/cancer-type/colorectal/risks/reducing-your-risk/?region=on]]
Health Provider Text:
Recommend patients:
•Be physically active
•Maintain a healthy body weight, [[bmi; https://cancer.ca/en/cancer-information/reduce-your-risk/have-a-healthy-body-weight/reduce-your-risk-of-cancer-with-a-healthy-body-weight]]
•Limit the amount of alcohol they drink (see healthy drinking guidelines)
•Be a non-smoker and avoid second hand smoke
•Limit the amount of red and processed meats eaten
•Eat foods high in fiber 
•Limit sitting time
[[Source; http://www.cancer.ca/en/cancer-information/cancer-type/colorectal/risks/reducing-your-risk/?region=on]]

•Diluted bleach recipe: 250 mL (1 cup) of water per 5 mL (1 teaspoon) of bleach. Directions are based on bleach that is 5% sodium hypochlorite, to give a 0.1% sodium hypochlorite solution. Never mix bleach with other chemical products and use it in a well-ventilated area.

Subject: Blood pressure
General Patient Text:
During your visit to the doctor, ask for a measurement of your blood pressure. 
A normal blood pressure is under 140/90 mmHg or lower for some people .
The target blood pressure depends on factors like age and health conditions, and where readings are being taken. If you have diabetes, kidney disease or other health conditions, speak to your health care professional about your target blood pressure. 

[[How to appropriately measure your blood pressure at home; https://hypertension.ca/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/BPM-Postcard-Front.jpg]]
[[Understanding and Managing Your Blood Pressure; https://guidelines.hypertension.ca/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/HTC_Brochure_UnderstandingBP_2018_R3.pdf]]
Health Provider Text:
CTFPHC recommends blood pressure measurement at all appropriate primary care visits.[[2012 Guideline; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/guidelines/published-guidelines/hypertension/]]
(Strong recommendation; moderate quality evidence)

If the mean blood pressure measured in office [[As per recommended technique; https://guidelines.hypertension.ca/diagnosis-assessment/measuring-blood-pressure/]] is high during one visit, a history and physical examination should be performed and, if clinically indicated, diagnostic tests to search for target organ damage should be arranged within 2 visits. 

Routine Lab Testing Recommended: urinalysis, blood chemistry (potassium, sodium and creatinine), fasting blood glucose and/or glycated hemoglobin (A1C), serum total cholesterol, LDL, HDL, non-HDL, triglycerides (fasting or non-fasting) and a standard 12-lead ECG. 

Global cardiovascular risk assessment should be done using [[risks calculators; www.ccs.ca/en/resources/calculators-forms]]

Subject: Cholesterol
General Patient Text:
Get tested over age 40 every 3-5 years.

Get tested under 40 only if you have 
some health problems:
•Family history of early heart disease 
•High blood pressure
•Diabetes
•Smoking
•[[and other health problems; https://www.heartandstroke.ca/heart/risk-and-prevention]]
Discuss this with your provider.

General Patient Text:
Over age 74
testing for cholesterol
may or may not 
be needed

•If you are healthy 
discuss testing with your practitioner
(most studies for cholesterol were not done on this age group
,so you may not need it).
•If you have health problems 
some health problems require cholesterol testing
and others do not,discuss with your provider.

Subject: Recommendations
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text:
Recommend the [[app CanImmunize; https://www.canimmunize.ca/en/home]]

AGE 18 and above (ALL ADULTS)
The following schedule assumes the patient has  been vaccinated in childhood
•Td (Tetanus-diphtheria) every 10 years
•Tdap(Tetanus,diphtheria, acellular pertussis or whooping cough):once in your lifetime
•Measles Mumps Rubella:it is advised that  most adults should have  2 doses of this vaccine
•HPV: recommended for all females and males from ages 9 to 26. The vaccine is also safe over age 26. [[more; https://www.reframehealthlab.com/should-you-get-the-hpv-vaccine/]]
•Influenza: is recommended for all adults. For high risk groups see CanImmunize app
•Pneumococcal, varicella,  meningococcal are recommended for some high risk groups seeCANImmunize app

AGE 50+
Shingrix,
Not covered in many provinces
[[more; https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/shingles/hcp/index.html


AGE 60+
Zostavax
Covered at different ages in some provinces,
Check your province's immunization schedule

AGE 65+ 
•Pneumococcal 
PNEU-P-23 advised for all immunocompetent,
repeat once in 5 years only if low immunity.
PNEU-C-13 advised for immunocompetent but not covered in most provinces.
BE AWARE OF SCHEDULING CORRECT TIME BETWEEN THESE VACCINES
•Pneu-C-13 vaccine should be provided first followed by Pneu-P-23 vaccine at least 8 weeks later.
•Adults aged 65 years and older who have previously received Pneu-P-23 can receive Pneu-C-13 vaccine if at least one year has passed since immunization with Pneu-P-23 vaccine.

•Influenza yearly

SOURCE: NACI: [[National Advisory Committe on Immunization; https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/immunization/national-advisory-committee-on-immunization-naci.html]]

Subject: Lung Cancer screening
General Patient Text: n/a
Health Provider Text:
The [[CTFPHC (2016); https://canadiantaskforce.ca/guidelines/published-guidelines/lung-cancer/]]  recommends a Low dose CT (LDCT) for
•	adults aged 55-74 years, 
•	with at least a 30 pack-year smoking history 
•	who currently smoke or quit less than 15 years ago. 
•	They recommend annual screening with LDCT up to three consecutive time. (Weak recommendation; low quality evidence)

For all other adults, regardless of age, smoking history or other risk factors, they do recommend not screening for lung cancer with LDCT. (Strong recommendation; very low quality evidence.)

There is an official screening program in some hospitals in [[Ontario; https://www.cancercareontario.ca/en/guidelines-advice/cancer-continuum/screening/lung-cancer-screening-information]].

Subject: What is Dementia?
General Patient Text:
Dementia is a type of disease 
that affects memory and thinking. 
This is different than memory loss from normal aging.
[[normal aging vs dementia; http://alzheimer.ca/en/Home/About-dementia/What-is-dementia/Normal-aging-vs-dementia]]
Dementia can have different causes:
•Alzheimer's disease
•Vascular Dementia (due to strokes)
•Correctable causes: Thyroid, Vitamin Deficiencies
[[more; http://alzheimer.ca/en/Home/About-dementia/What-is-dementia]]

Subject: Prevention of Dementia
General Patient Text:
•Be physically active
•Eat a healthy diet
•Maintain a healthy weight/BMI
•Don’t smoke or drink excessive alcohol
•Keep your blood pressure, blood sugar and cholesterol in a healthy range
•Stay connected socially
•Challenge your brain with games, learning
•Reduce stress
•Protect your head with a helmet in sports 

[[more; http://alzheimer.ca/en/simcoecounty/About-dementia/Alzheimer-s-disease/Risk-factors]]
Health Provider Text:
Recommend your patients:
•Be physically active
•Eat a healthy diet
•Maintain a healthy weight/BMI
•Don’t smoke or drink excessive alcohol
•Keep their blood pressure, blood sugar and cholesterol in a healthy range
•Stay connected socially
•Challenge their brain with games, learning
•Reduce stress
•Protect their head with a helmet in sports 
[[more; http://alzheimer.ca/en/simcoecounty/About-dementia/Alzheimer-s-disease/Risk-factors]]

Subject: Sexual health
General Patient Text:
•	If you are on testosterone and have not had a hysterectomy (removal of the uterus), you need to use reliable form of birth control if there is a risk pregnancy based on your sexual practices, as testosterone can cause birth defects.
•	If you are trying to or could become pregnant (based on your sexual practices), discuss this with your primary care provider, as taking a folic acid vitamin is important
•	Condoms are recommended for anal sex.
•HIV testing is recommended for all Canadians at least once [[PHAC guidelines; https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/hiv-aids/hiv-screening-testing-guide.html]] 
•Depending on your sexual practices and history, screening for sexually transmitted infections and HIV may be recommended at different times. Discuss any concerns you may have with your primary care provider.
• If you have been the receptive partner during anal sex (“bottom”), your primary care provider may recommend regular anal Pap tests.
• [[WHO guidelines; https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/128048/9789241507431_eng.pdf?sequence=1]]
• [[RHO guidelines; https://www.rainbowhealthontario.ca/wp-content/uploads/woocommerce_uploads/2019/12/Guidelines-FINAL-Dec-2019-iw2oti.pdf]]
• [[UCSF Transcare guidelines; https://transcare.ucsf.edu/sites/transcare.ucsf.edu/files/Transgender-PGACG-6-17-16.pdf]]
Health Provider Text:
•	Those on testosterone who have not undergone hysterectomy need reliable birth control if pregnancy is a risk based on sexual activity, as testosterone is a teratogen (RHO).
•	If pregnancy is possible based on sexual activity, follow the same folic acid recommendations as for cis women.
•	Condoms are recommended for anal sex.
•	Emphasize adequate provision of lubricants for trans women and trans men who have sex with men.
•Screen all Canadians for HIV at least once as per [[PHAC guidelines; https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/hiv-aids/hiv-screening-testing-guide.html]] 
•Screen for STIs based on behavioural history and sexual practices.
•Consider anal Pap tests every 2-3 years (or yearly in those who are HIV+) for those who have a history of receptive anal sex (RHO).
•In the LGBTQ+ community, the terms “bottom” and “top” are often used to describe the receptive and penetrative partners during sexual activity, respectively. The term “versatile” is used to describe someone who may alternate between these roles.
• [[WHO guidelines; https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/128048/9789241507431_e ng.pdf?sequence=1]]
• [[RHO guidelines; https://www.rainbowhealthontario.ca/wp-content/uploads/woocommerce_uploads/2019/12/Guidelines-FINAL-Dec-2019-iw2oti.pdf]]
• [[UCSF Transcare guidelines; https://transcare.ucsf.edu/sites/transcare.ucsf.edu/files/Transgender-PGACG-6-17-16.pdf]]

Subject: Contraception
General Patient Text:
•If you are on testosterone and have not had a hysterectomy (removal of the uterus), you need to use a reliable form of birth control if there is a risk pregnancy based on your sexual practices, as testosterone can cause birth defects.
• For contraception hormonal methods (such as the "pill") can be used when taking testosterone.
•Barrier methods(condoms) are recommended for all.
Health Provider Text:
•Those on testosterone who have not undergone hysterectomy need reliable birth control if pregnancy is a risk based on sexual activity, as testosterone is a teratogen (RHO).
•Any hormonal/methods can be used (no contraindications with testosterone)

Subject: Cervical Cancer
General Patient Text:
•If you have not had surgery to remove the cervix (the lower part of the uterus leading to the vagina), you need regular cervical cancer screening.
•Pap tests are recommended every 3 years from age 21-69 if you have ever been sexually active.
•If you think your cervix was removed during surgery, discuss the need for Pap tests with your primary care provider.
• [[Overview of cervical cancer screening for trans men in Canada; https://www.cancer.ca/en/prevention-and-screening/reduce-cancer-risk/find-cancer-early/screening-in-lgbtq-communities/trans-men-and-cervical-cancer-screening/?region=on]]
• [[RHO guidelines; https://www.rainbowhealthontario.ca/wp-content/uploads/woocommerce_uploads/2019/12/Guidelines-FINAL-Dec-2019-iw2oti.pdf]]
• [[UCSF Transcare guidelines; https://transcare.ucsf.edu/guidelines/cervical-cancer]]
• [[Endocrine Society guidelines; https://academic.oup.com/jcem/article/102/11/3869/4157558]]
Health Provider Text:
•	Trans men and people on the transmasculine spectrum who still have a cervix should undergo cervical cancer screening as per current guidelines.
•	Pap tests are recommended every 3 years from age 21-69 if the person has ever been sexually active.
• A trial of vaginal estrogens for 1 week prior to the exam may be helpful (RHO, UCSF).
• Should speculum examination be painful or difficult due to vaginal atrophy, consider applying topical 2% lidocaine jelly vaginally 5-10 minutes prior to the procedure (RHO).
• Consider administering a low-dose lorazepam pre-procedurally if the patient is particularly anxious about the exam (RHO, UCSF).
• Use a paediatric speculum if possible to reduce discomfort.
• If speculum insertion remains difficult, suggest allowing the patient to insert the speculum themselves or watching the procedure using a mirror (UCSF).
• Note that unsatisfactory samples of Pap tests are far more common in trans men compared to cis women and that repeats may be required; ensure to note if the patient is/was on testosterone on the cytology requisition (UCSF, RHO), as cervical atrophy can mimic dysplasia (WHO).
• [[Overview of cervical cancer screening for trans men in Canada; https://www.cancer.ca/en/prevention-and-screening/reduce-cancer-risk/find-cancer-early/screening-in-lgbtq-communities/trans-men-and-cervical-cancer-screening/?region=on]]
• [[Tips for physical examination of trans patients; https://transcare.ucsf.edu/guidelines/physical-examination]]
• [[Tips on performing Pap tests for  trans men; https://www.rainbowhealthontario.ca/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/Tips_Paps_TransMen-1.jpg]]
•[[VIDEO: Do's and Dont's when performing  Paps with trans men; https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KIfSjX1ZEU4]]
•  [[Tips on improving trans men’s experiences with Pap tests; https://transcare.ucsf.edu/guidelines/cervical-cancer]]

• [[RHO guidelines; https://www.rainbowhealthontario.ca/wp-content/uploads/woocommerce_uploads/2019/12/Guidelines-FINAL-Dec-2019-iw2oti.pdf]]
• [[UCSF Transcare guidelines; https://transcare.ucsf.edu/guidelines/cervical-cancer]]
• [[Endocrine Society guidelines; https://academic.oup.com/jcem/article/102/11/3869/4157558]]

Subject: Sexual health
General Patient Text:
•  HIV testing is recommended for all Canadians at least once [[PHAC guidelines; https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/hiv-aids/hiv-screening-testing-guide.html]] 
• Depending on your sexual practices and history, screening for sexually transmitted infections and HIV may be recommended at different times.  Discuss any concerns you may have with your primary care provider.
• Condoms are recommended for anal sex.
• If you have been the receptive partner during anal sex (“bottom”), your primary care provider may recommend regular anal Pap tests.
• If you have sex with men, have concerns about HIV prevention and would like to know more about pre- exposure prophylaxis (PrEP), discuss this with your primary care provider.
• [[WHO guidelines; https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/128048/9789241507431_eng.pdf?sequence=1]]
• [[RHO guidelines; https://www.rainbowhealthontario.ca/wp-content/uploads/woocommerce_uploads/2019/12/Guidelines-FINAL-Dec-2019-iw2oti.pdf]]
• [[UCSF Transcare guidelines; https://transcare.ucsf.edu/sites/transcare.ucsf.edu/files/Transgender-PGACG-6-17-16.pdf]]
Health Provider Text:
• Emphasize adequate provision of lubricants for trans women and trans men who have sex with men.
•Screen all Canadians for HIV at least once as per [[PHAC guidelines; https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/hiv-aids/hiv-screening-testing-guide.html]] 
• Screen for STIs based on behavioural history and sexual practices.
• Condoms are recommended for anal sex.
• Consider anal Pap tests every 2-3 years (or yearly in those who are HIV+) for those who have a history of receptive anal sex (RHO).
• Daily oral pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) may be considered as a possible additional intervention for trans women who have sex with men (WHO).
• Voluntary medical circumcision (VMMC) is not recommended for HIV prevention among transgender women (WHO).       
• In the LGBTQ+ community, the terms “bottom” and “top” are often used to describe the receptive and penetrative partners during sexual activity, respectively. The term “versatile” is used to describe someone who may alternate between these roles.
• [[WHO guidelines; https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/128048/9789241507431_eng.pdf?sequence=1]]
• [[RHO guidelines; https://www.rainbowhealthontario.ca/wp-content/uploads/woocommerce_uploads/2019/12/Guidelines-FINAL-Dec-2019-iw2oti.pdf]]
• [[UCSF Transcare guidelines; https://transcare.ucsf.edu/sites/transcare.ucsf.edu/files/Transgender-PGACG-6-17-16.pdf]]

Subject: Contraception
General Patient Text: Use barrier method (and/or have partner use hormonal contraception) if no bottom surgery and having intercourse with partner who could get pregnant
Health Provider Text: Recommendation is to use a barrier method (and/or have partner use hormonal contraception) if no bottom surgery and having intercourse with partner who could get pregnant.

Subject: Prostate
General Patient Text:
You have a prostate if you were assigned male sex at birth.Bottom surgery does not remove the prostate.
To prevent prostate cancer:
•Eat a healthy diet.
•Be active most days of the week.
•Keep your weight at a healthy level.
[[What is prostate cancer?; http://www.cancer.ca/en/cancer-information/cancer-type/prostate/prostate-cancer/?region=on]]
[[Risks; http://www.cancer.ca/en/cancer-information/cancer-type/prostate/risks/?region=on]]
 Testing for prostate cancer with the psa test is not recommended in Canada at this time . For more information choose : male age 55 to 69 on this app.
Health Provider Text: Same as cis men (bottom surgery does not remove the prostate)

Subject: Cervical Cancer
General Patient Text:
•Most trans women and non-binary people on the transfeminine spectrum do not need any cervical cancer screening, regardless of whether or not they have had a vaginoplasty.
•In the very rare instance where you would have had a cervix created during vaginoplasty, discuss the need for Pap tests with your primary care provider.
•If you have had a vaginoplasty, your primary care provider may suggest yearly visual examination with a speculum.
•[[Overview of cervical cancer screening for trans women in Canada; https://www.cancer.ca/en/prevention-and-screening/reduce-cancer-risk/find-cancer-early/screening-in-lgbtq-communities/trans-women-and-cervical-cancer-screening/?region=on]]
• [[RHO guidelines; https://www.rainbowhealthontario.ca/wp-content/uploads/woocommerce_uploads/2019/12/Guidelines-FINAL-Dec-2019-iw2oti.pdf]]
• [[UCSF Transcare guidelines; https://transcare.ucsf.edu/guidelines/cervical-cancer]]
• [[Endocrine Society guidelines; https://academic.oup.com/jcem/article/102/11/3869/4157558]] (Can be the same suggestions as for cisgender patients)
Health Provider Text:
•Trans women and people on the transfeminine spectrum generally do not need any cervical cancer screening as vaginoplasty does not usually entail creation of a neocervix.
•Neovagina vault testing is not recommended.
•In the very rare instances where a neocervix may have been created during vaginoplasty (such as from the skin of the glans penis), consider following the current cervical cancer screening guidelines for cis women (ACOG) (Pap tests are recommended every 3 years from age 21 to 69 if the person has ever been sexually active).
•Consider annual neovaginal speculum examination to visually detect any abnormalities (including malignancy) for those who have undergone vaginoplasty (RHO).
•	Neovaginas may have a more posterior orientation than those of cis women, and using an anoscope rather than a speculum may be more appropriate for examination (UCSF).
•	[[Overview of cervical cancer screening for trans women in Canada; https://www.cancer.ca/en/prevention-and-screening/reduce-cancer-risk/find-cancer-early/screening-in-lgbtq-communities/trans-women-and-cervical-cancer-screening/?region=on]]
•	[[Tips for physical examination of trans patients; https://transcare.ucsf.edu/guidelines/physical-examination]]
•	[[RHO guidelines; https://www.rainbowhealthontario.ca/wp-content/uploads/woocommerce_uploads/2019/12/Guidelines-FINAL-Dec-2019-iw2oti.pdf]]
•	[[UCSF Transcare guidelines; https://transcare.ucsf.edu/guidelines/cervical-cancer]]
•	[[Endocrine Society guidelines; https://academic.oup.com/jcem/article/102/11/3869/4157558]]

Subject: Stop Skin Cancer
General Patient Text:
•Wear protective clothing
•Limit time in the sun (worst time: between 10 am and 3 pm) 
•Wear sunscreen (minimum SPF 30) 
•[[Avoid tanning booth and sun beds; https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/services/sun-safety/tanning-beds-lamps.html]]
[[More info; https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/sun-safety/skin-cancer.html]]
Health Provider Text:
To prevent Melanoma:
Decrease exposure to sun with:protective clothing, sunscreen min SPF 30
[[CTFPHC appraised guideline 2014;https://canadiantaskforce.ca/guidelines/appraised-guidelines/melanoma/]]
Clinical assessment of future risk of melanoma take into account:
- person’s age and sex
- history of previous melanoma or non-melanoma skin cancer
- family history of melanoma
- number of naevi (common and atypical)
- skin and hair pigmentation
- response to sun exposure
- evidence of actinic skin damage

Health Provider Text:
Vision screening:
Consensus only recommendation from Canadian Ophthalmol Society 2007
Currently in many provinces this would be done by optometrists
New guideline available soon.

If high risk more frequent screening advised than below.
HIgh risk:African American, high myopia,diabetes or hypertension.

•18-40 every 10 years
•41-55 every 5 years
•56-64 every 3 years
•65 and above every year

As per [[CTFPH 2013 guidelines; https://canadiantaskforce.ca/guidelines/published-guidelines/depression/]] : Screening for depression is not recommended for adults at average risk of depression who present to a primary care setting, with no apparent symptoms of depression. However primary care providers know the importance of mental health and how it influences overall health. Below are some resources.
